document.title: South Carolina Academic Standards for Physical Education

03BA29448AB24F65B488C869A6119206.description: Identify his or her likes and dislikes with regard to participating in physical activities.

59A7E5EF887F454C8F7A22505416CC1B.description: Continue to participate/practice in physical activities after being unsuccessful in initial attempts.

8DB58387F1E7493D89C3296AC9F6F824.description: Demonstrate a willingness to learn new fundamental movement skills and try new games.

157413DA80FE44F7B7B548A8E63E22A1.description: Identify feelings resulting from participation in physical activities (for example, sense of excitement after running a 25 meter dash or completing the fun run).

A16BB7A0EDC04FBE86D9CB78D071BEA1.description: Participate willingly in individual and group physical activities.

5D1315EAD0704EF384210B45B111D907.description: The physically literate individual demonstrates awareness that physical activity provides the opportunity for health, enjoyment, challenge, self-expression and/or social interaction. (Affective Domain)

D848EB2761794178929BF472ADE26D27.description: Participate appropriately as a member of the class by following directions and classroom rules and using safe physical-activity practices.

FE8BF82FBC1A4BD09BDC3F8782B1093B.description: Work independently and with others on physical education tasks.

C0004D84864B470DB9447D790035D65D.description: Interact positively with others in physical-activity settings (for example, treating others with respect during physical activity regardless of personal differences, including gender, skill level, or ethnicity).

DCAAA7F19FDE47A68468EFE20F4F4730.description: Share physical-activity space and equipment willingly with others.

D589FD2307A94A8689A022E708A8F799.description: The physically literate individual exhibits responsible personal and social behavior that respects self and others in physical-activity settings. (Affective Domain)

C85A77D6DFE043688FEFDF5BC5896052.description: Engage in a variety of physical activities during leisure time (for example, t-ball, riding a bicycle, tag, hide-and-seek).

0DD0F2AD88704B37A829CF018759C1DE.description: Demonstrate muscular strength by supporting body weight for climbing, hanging, and momentarily supporting weight on hands (for example, maintaining a push-up position).

55F87960ED3F42609744B6D5DC781433.description: Engage in sustained physical activity that causes an increased heart rate, and rapid breathing.

023878BAA9A742E1940281774D6C26EB.description: Sustain moderate-to-vigorous physical activity for short periods of time.

FD65CA5A30EA4046917F3EDF26D21C1B.description: The physically literate individual achieves and maintains a health-enhancing level of physical activity and fitness. (Psychomotor Domain)

073B9EE8621D422FA95B1BDD1D5306BE.description: Identify the physiological effects of moderate physical activity (for example, fast heart rate, rapid breathing, increase body temperature).

50C95EF0450D4BBE848767A6A29DC779.description: Identify a variety of spatial relationships with objects (for example, over, under, behind, beside, through).

6BE250F2D0AF46F9A7E427B9267F2DFC.description: Identify basic body and space awareness movement concepts (for example, body parts, body shapes, non-locomotor movements such as bend and twist, personal and general space, high and low levels, directions, and pathways).

6D2B653CFC5B4CB68561EFD93333DBD0.description: Identify fundamental movement skills (for example, hop, jump, gallop, slide, catch, throw, strike).

FA92EF2CFEC34A47BBB7EBA261523171.description: The physically literate individual demonstrates knowledge of concepts, principles, strategies and tactics related to movement and performance. (Cognitive Domain)

4AD2EBF9DD154A3ABAC11C641C9FCAA6.description: Throw, catch, kick, and strike objects in simple conditions (for example, tossing and catching in personal space, kicking and striking a stationary ball).

D2D94CE3916E49B2B208C61E9C980300.description: Demonstrate controlled traveling, rolling, and balancing actions with or without equipment.

DFE6BC7DBC86438C9AEBC55DBE182AD1.description: Support body weight on a variety of body parts while maintaining stillness (for example, balancing on two hands and a foot).

208880F86F3B4EBA8DE628312A05C89A.description: Demonstrate beat awareness by moving to even and uneven rhythms (for example, galloping or sliding to the uneven rhythm of a drum beat or music).

723FB5B7AE0B408B9532A5617C5F31B4.description: Move in general space in a controlled manner to avoid contact with people and objects and be able to stop in control on command.

1DA3C38D02904FDCB0666C9C09322548.description: Travel with control forward and sideways using a variety of locomotor skills (including run, jump, hop, gallop, and slide) and change directions in response to a signal or obstacle.

0789630AB06942B0A0C2F70945BD3D3E.description: The physically literate individual demonstrates competency in a variety of motor skills and movement patterns. (Psychomotor Domain)
